item.text: Referred to the House Committee on House Administration.

bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 163, Number 195 (Thursday, November 30, 2017)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. DESANTIS:H.R. 4494.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 5, Clause 2 (``Each House may determinethe Rules of its Proceedings, punish its Members fordisorderly Behaviour, and, with the Concurrence of twothirds, expel a Member.'').[Page H9569]

item.title: Congressional Accountability and Hush Fund Elimination Act

To amend the Congressional Accountability Act of 1995 to prohibit the use of public funds to pay awards and settlements in connection with claims under such Act which arise from sexual harassment, and for other purposes.
Congressional Accountability and Hush Fund Elimination Act
Congressional Accountability and Hush Fund Elimination Act

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
